title: How is it that others think there are no descendants of Cleopatra VII? Cleopatra was my grandmother 47 times validated. - Quora

response.answer_text: Cleopatra's line did not end with her as you said. Her daughter and youngest two sons, her children with Mark Antony, outlived her and their father and where brought back to Rome were they where raised in Octavian/Augustus' household, and while of the two sons one most likely died from disease relatively early and the fate of the other is almost entirely unknown the daughter, Cleopatra Selene II, however grew up and was married to Juba II, who had also been raised in Augustus' home and further was the heir to the Roman client kingdom Mauritania. After their marriage that couple ruled Mauritania from Caesarea(modern Cherchell, Algeria) and had one son, Ptolemy of Mauretania. He was the king famously lured to Rome and executed by Caligula, but he also left a daughter, Drusilla. Drusilla was first married to a Greek named Antonius Felix, but was later divorced by him as he fell in love with another woman, Drusillas second marriage was then with the Priest King of Emesa Sohaemus. Drusillas descendants then became the Royal family of Emesa, who while they where eventually stripped of their royal status when Emessa was absorbed into the Roman province of Syria maintained their hereditary position as high priests of the Sun God Elagabalus. This until one of daughter, Julia Domna, of this family was prophesied to be destined to marry a future king, a man named Septimius Severus allegedly heard this legend and tracke her down and married her. She bore him two sons, today known to us as Caracalla and Geta, and following year of the five emperors Septimius Severus came out as the founder of the Sevaran dynasty. When he died Caracalla and Geta inherited the Roman empire and after them the grandchildren of Julia Domnas sister, Julia Maesa, Elagabalus and Alexander Severus also got their turns as Emperors. Alexander Severus is then generally being viewed as the last Emperor of the Principate, meaning a direct descendant of Cleopatra saw the end of the Imperial order established by the man responsible for her death.﻿

The children we know about - she is not recorded to have produced children from the marriage with her brother: Caesarion, son of Julius Caesar; killed before fathering any children we know of.Then, with Mark Antony: Cleopatra Selene II, who married Juba II of Numidia; she had two children:Ptolemy, King of MauretaniaDrusillaHer twin brother: Alexander Helios - disappeared while a child hostage of Antonia Minor, almost certainly killed.Another brother: Ptolemy Philadelphus also disappeared whilst a child in Rome. Killed also.So only one child - Cleopatra Selene II, is available. Her son, Ptolemy had issue: Drusilla, Queen of Emesa; her son was Gaius Julius Alexio “After the death of Alexio, the generations after him are not recorded sufficiently to accurately present a pedigree.[11]” And her daughter Drusilla of Mauretania the Elder “It has been suggested that she was the first wife of Antonius Felix, Procurator of Judea.” Maybe, but I think not - his interest was another Drusilla. Doesn’t look good for making a modern, genealogical connection.

She had descendants. It's just pointless to guess at who they are without a verified sample of her DNA. Likely a huge portion of the population of places once ruled by Rome have her somewhere in their genealogy. Now, I think your claim that Cleopatra was my grandmother 47 times validated. Seems unlikely. It's possible that she is an ancestor, but the number of generations seems off. Cleopatra died in 30BC. Even if she had had a child that same year that makes for 2048 years between then and now. Now as you claim her to be Great x47 Grandma that means that there are 49 ancestors between you and her. Even if you are the oldest living person at 117 years old , that means that the average age of each ancestor when the next generation was born was 39 years old. Assuming that you had a mix of male and female ancestors, your female ancestors would be having kids unusually late and your male ancestors would be quite ancient with respect to their spouses.

I’m not sure who you think believes that. It’s reasonably well documented that Cleopatra did have descendants. Cleopatra’s known family tree extends for several more generations after her death, though things do eventually become quite doubtful after a while. That said, how has it been validated that Cleopatra is your ancestor? There are all kinds of family legends about people’s ancestry which are, it turns out, completely false. There are any number of people in the US, for example, who claim Cherokee ancestry, but it doesn’t take more than a little genetic testing to prove that one way or another. Now, if you’ve had DNA testing establishing a relationship with Cleopatra, then that’s excellent. However, absent that or a 2000 year long chain of documentary evidence establishing your personal links with the Ptolemaic dynasty, let me gently suggest that there are other, more plausible explanations for your belief in a particularly glamorous ancestor.

Cleopatra VII’s children with Marcus Antonius survived the Actium. While Ptolemy Philadelphus and Alexander Helios died somewhere after 30 BCE without offspring, Cleopatra Selene married the King of Mauretania and left some descendants. Drusilla Minor, the niece of the last King of Mauretania, left a line of descendants, with Zenobia of Palmyra possibly being her descendant. However, any claim of being descended from Drusilla minor could not be verified.
That will have taken some pretty clever validation, given that nobody knows for certain where Cleopatra VII was buried.
